. It includes northern Bristol County and some Norfolk county towns.

value: "Jewelry Capital of the World" and home to the LaSalette Shrine.
- Also home to the Dighton Rock State Park.
- Home to the mysterious Dighton Rock (the official "Explorer Rock" of Massachusetts.)
- Home to Stonehill College, The Rockery, and
provided shovels which laid the Union Pacific Railroad.
- Home to the Tweeter Center for the Performing Arts.
- The early mid-19th century leading producer of buttons in the country.
- Home to Wheaton College and the Tournament Players Club of Boston (part of the PGA Tour's Deutsche Bank Championship.)
- Site of the first iron works in America, a big milk bottle, and produced the anchor for the Civil War-era ironclad USS Monitor.
- Claims to be one of the birthplaces of public education in North America and
Guinness Book of Records for the town with the most golf courses in the U.S.
- "The Silver City" and "The Christmas City", the seat of Bristol County, a regional hub, the center of the "Bridgewater Triangle", and a city rich in history.
- Birthplace of noted author William Taylor Adams (aka Oliver Optic) and home to the new Dunkin' Donuts Northeast Distribution Center.
- Headquarters of Reebok, Baskin Robbins, etc., and claims to have been the birthplace of Rising Sun Stove Polish as well as the pay toilet.
- For Cryptozoologists and other curious bystanders, it is the home of the mysterious creature called the "Dover Demon."
- Home of Gillette Stadium, the New England Patriots, and New England Revolution; also, was home to the
world's largest straw hat making factory.
- Named in honor of Dr. Benjamin Franklin; also, the birthplace of the nation's first lending library and Horace Mann (America's father of public education.)
- Home to one of the ten oldest homes in the U.S., the "lost treasure" of Davis Wolfgang Hawke, and
vacation spot of Walter Elias Disney (aka - Walt Disney.)
- Birthplace of famed U.S. outdoorsman James/John Capen "Grizzly" Adams.
- Home to the Sikh Temple "Guru Ram Das Ashram and Gurdwara."
- Area site of one of the original five houses built on the old Indian Trail from Medfield to Wrentham.
- Has one of the lowest crimes rates in the country.
- Named for William Stoughton (the notorious Chief Justice at the Salem Witch Trials) and the site of the written Suffolk Resolves, which was the basis of the Declaration of Independence.
- Named after Sir Robert Walpole (the first Prime Minister of Great Britain) and home to one of two of the state's Supermax prisons.
